note.body:
Stepping through gjs_debug_flat_string() shows that

    "size_t len = js::GetLinearStringLength(str);"

is returning a large number. However a few lines later the string returned from

    "const char16_t *chars = js::GetTwoByteLinearStringChars(nogc, str);"

is invalid length and the first attempt to index into it segfaults at index 0

    "char16_t c = chars[ix];"

I wonder if the real problem though is that a few lines earlier the call to

    "if (js::LinearStringHasLatin1Chars(str))"

returns false even though the str->flags is set to (decimal) 74 so the

    "flags & shadow::String::LATIN1_CHARS_BIT"

line should be true. Is this possibly a big endian issue with the way that constant is generated via bit shifting?

events.target_title: Add a vte-urlencode utility and a tcsh conterpart to vte.sh

note.body:
My meson knowledge is near zero. How do I make it install vte-urlencode at libexecdir?

I kept the ability to use argv[1] because it's useful for testing (check src/test-vte-sh.sh, which by the way will need to be updated too).

I will use $PWD instead of getcwd().

The "& 0xff" prevents propagating a leading 1 bit to the left when converting from char to int, otherwise we get this:

```
$ /tmp/vte-urlencode /ação
/a%FFFFFFC3%FFFFFFA7%FFFFFFC3%FFFFFFA3o
```

events.target_title: Wacom stylus screen mode bug.

note.body:
Sadly GIMP (and/or GTK+) isn't entirely predictable when it comes to tablet problems....

I've never had problems with XP-Pen Star 06 [wireless painting tablet](https://www.xp-pen.com/product/49.html) on my GIMP installation (aside from the occasional failure to detect the tablet at all), unfortunately I'm not quite sure I understand the description. Nonetheless, here's a few quick things to check / rule out:

- Screen/window mode. It should definitely be set to "Screen", so this doesn't seem to be the cause....

- Pen/mouse mode. If, for example, you pick up the pen from point A and put it down on point B but the cursor doesn't immediately snap to the new location, then you've got the stylus set on mouse (relative movement) mode. Check your Wacom tablet control panel to be sure it's on Pen (absolute movement) mode.

events.target_title: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/shotwell/issues/183
Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)
Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)

note.body:
I executed callgrind and perf, they both report this:
+ Inclusive   Self    Process   Module                  Function
+   49.58%    49.57%  xsltproc  libxml2.so.2.9.1    [.] xmlStrncat
+   48.62%    48.61%  xsltproc  libxml2.so.2.9.1    [.] xmlStrlen

basically meaning that most of the time is used copying strings and measuring strings in my use case.
for the test case, I am going to check.

It seems that maintaing the size of text nodes and the xmlNode could have a huge impact on performance, using some "copy-on-write" or immutable text logic could cut execution time by a big factor

events.target_title: Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)

note.body:
The path is starting under xsltApplySequenceConstructor:
- xsltValueOf => xsltCopyTextString => xsltAddTextString
- xsltCopyText => xsltAddTextString
then
- xsltAddTextString => xmlStrnlen (half of the time)
- xsltAddTextString => xmlNodeAddContent => xmlNodeAddContentLen => xmlStrncat (the other half)

events.target_title: Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)

note.body:
After some debugging, I understand what happens: 
* we use EXSLT and concatenation cache is NULLed any time a EXSLT function is called (cannot grasp why there is code duplication is this region btw), "cur->pswi == xsltExtMarker ==> ctxt->lasttext = NULL"
* we use xsl:variable quite a lot as our XSL is pretty complex, there is only one such "lasttext", but when xsl:variable elements are encountered a new target node is created, and first concatenation empties "lasttext" and when interned string are copied to it "lasttext" is invalidated as well

For problem 1, using systematically xsltAddChild in libexslt could bring the opportunity to ensure that the "lasttext" cache is invalidated properly and thus avoid the cache systematic trashing. Another way is to invalidate only for the few functions that actually do xmlAddChild... my preference goes to ensure that the cache is never trashed
For problem 2, probably need to a few entries, not just one, maybe just 2, top level + first level of xsl:variable

A more impacting solution would be to do some homework in libxml2, supporting a new type of "dynamic text node", which would allow efficient concatenation (putting lasttuse/lasttsize in xmlNode more or less), simplifying drastically all of this. 

If you want I can work on that and try a patch.

events.target_title: Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)

note.body:
Indeed could append text nodes and coalesce them when we are finished with the direct parent node, a single scan per node, gathering sequences of text and replacing them with a single text node for each, linear time.
Possible ?

events.target_title: In Print -> Image settings, the Center selection is reset when scaling the size.
In Print -> Image settings, the Center selection is reset when scaling the size.

note.body:
Having studied the code, I see that the **various on_*_value_changed** calls cannot distinguish if they are called by the user/GTK directly or are called as a consequence of the adjustment of other Buttons.

For example: When user sets the **Center** to **Both** it will (possibly) need to adjust the values of **Left**, **Top** etc. However, If the user presses the **-** or **+** of **Left** directly, you would like to modify the **Center** value from **Both** to **Vertical**, as only the horizontal part is non-centered anymore.

I assume this conflict can be solved by making **adjust_*_value** (similar as the **on_*_value_changed** functions) which firstly block the trigger, secondly modify the value and finally unblock the trigger.

events.target_title: In Print -> Image settings, the Center selection is reset when scaling the size.

note.body: It seems the signal [value-changed](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/stable/GtkSpinButton.html#GtkSpinButton-value-changed) is already emitted if the SpinButton gets into focus, but has no value changed. This means that repetitively pressing the Tab key will force an update of each of the value. The image will move due to rounding errors.

[jarekb@madcow ~]$ sudo openconnect -b --protocol=pulse ra.comp.com.pl/compsa
[sudo] hasło użytkownika jarekb:

Regards

events.target_title: NetworkManager openconnect fails to connect with immediate failure

note.body:
We looked at it once again and definately the problem is with parsing gateway strings. NM-OpenConnect assumes that all users are connecting to Pulse Server without realm string i.e. ra.comp.com.pl and change this into https://ra.comp.com.pl when executing openconnect with parameters.

Our case is we are usings realm and assigned sign-in paged to it. That is when user connect to ra.comp.com.pl/compa (/compsa is the sign-in page for that realm). As we see whatewer you fill in gateway part of form is truncated to FQDN without URL /compsa at the end. Since we do not have default sign-in page defines Pulse Server returns error "The page you requested could not be found.". I do personally think that we are facing improperly parsed gateway problem here. I think resolution would be to keep whole GATEWAY string as-is and pass it to executable.

Interesting part is that when we use Juniper as protocol everything is parsed properly :-)

Are there any developers reviewing issues here? 

Regards
J.

events.target_title: PNG gAMA chunk is silently ignored

note.body:
This is part of the PNG specification and GIMP should implement the specification right. PNG's specification is remarkably simple compared to some other formats. In particular the specification tells that if a gAMA chunk is present and the chunks iCCP, sRGB and cHRM are absent, then the application has to take gAMA into account. GIMP should do all its possible to render the image as close as possible to what it is supposed to look like. The gamma Display Filter option seems to prove that this could be programmed fairly easily in GIMP, and would not require any resampling of the image.

If it is too hard to achieve (because the program GIMP may not know what is actual effective gamma (the gamma from the channel values sent to the operating system to the actual pixel on the display) ), there should at least be some /coherence/ between the possibilities. By coherence I precisely mean the following:  if the user is able to set their display and os settings so that an sRGB image is displayed right, then all other color modes should also display right as per the PNG specification.

As a matter of fact, there are computer rendered images that are encoded with gamma=1 (they use a linear color coding).

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
could I ask one more question ? the way I see it, the source of the problem is not the fact that vte *is* overriding these chars, but the fact that it's decision whether to do so or not is a bit over-cautious. My point is that the font that I'm using (and I've tried couple of them) do have the characters inside the font so there's no need to manually render them.

if it would be possible, I would like to help in solving this issue. I may not be the best coder out there, but this issue, believe me or not, is important to me. Here's couple of solutions that I came up with:

1/ inside `_vte_draw_unichar_is_local_graphic` - check whether the font has the character implemented. Unfortunetely, I can see that the function only receives a char as a parameter, however it's not like the font is changed everytime the char is rendered, therefore I could imagine that a constructor (or some other function which is called once font instance is assigned) could check this and create a hashmap of supported characters and then this infamous function could check against such a hashmap and actually know which chars are missing and need to be manually rendered. In other words - if there is a font which is very basic and lacks glyphs then it would still use the shaded blocks. I do understand the rationale behind this functionality and do not want to dispute it - I would just like to tweak it a bit.

2/ create an option to override `_vte_draw_unichar_is_local_graphic` result. In other words, if I know that I'm using a font which has all these glyphs, I could just select an option in gnome-terminal and be happy. Even if I'd have to manually enter hex values, it would still be an improvement

3/ environmental variable of the above - which seems very hacky and ugly and has the least likelihood of success.

currently, as I understand the only thing that I can do is to:

1/ use non-vte emulator like xterm, konsole
2/ compile my own version of vte and replace the system one
3/ repeate the above everytime there's an gnome stack update

this seems like a massive overkill, especially given that I do have the glyphs in the font in the first place :-)

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
well, just for reference - this is from urxvt, the chars are loaded from font and that's an ncurses window where I put them next to each other. It all displays perfectly. I was completely unaware that this decision (to override rendering of the glyphs) was made based on font-irrelevant issues. My point is simply that these 2 or 3 glyphs in question are rendered wrong. A triangle is still a triangle, even if you move it up or down couple of pixels. A smiley is still a smiley, but a checkerboard/brick pattern is not a solid block. In this regard, using rxvt is not a free choice at all, since gnome-terminal doesn't allow me to use a font I know does have a char. Konsole has an option to render the glyphs like you pointed out, but gnome-terminal does not.

![2591-urxvt](/uploads/81cdd80919bebaa01638ec82be8910d9/2591-urxvt.png)

I don't want to pick up a flamewar though, you have explained everything quite nicely. Thank you :)

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
> That's not correct. Nothing in these characters' specification says they should be using a checkerboard or brick pattern. They are 'light/medium/dark shade', and their display as dots in the fonts is simply due to dithering being the way to achieve an approximation of the true rendering

I believe we are talking about two different things. You are talking about a unicode specification and I'm talking about a font. That's why we have fonts in the first place. If somebody doesn't like how an "o" character looks like, he can pick another font, in which an "o" would be a small dot, or an ellipse instead of a circle. That's why there are some fonts which have some of the digits below the center line (e.g. https://cdncms.fonts.net/images/c098e4e88991a263/A_Oldstyle_Figures.jpg ). If memory serves me correctly, back in the days there was a font called... webdings ? which took it to the whole new level and replaced the "regular" charcodes with some graphics. The user chooses a font knowingly and willingly. I can of course agree that you do not find the bricked pattern visually appealing, but this is a matter of personal taste, not what the font provides you with. I find them way more appealing than the shaded versions, but that's actually not my concern. My concern is that - why would you render an, say, "capital A" character (0x0041) by using a font-provided glyph, but you don't think it's a good idea for 0x2551? Again, I would like to stress out that I would **totally** understand this behavior of the code had the font not provided a glyph - in the end you have to display something on the screen, right?. But if the user chooses a font that he finds aesthetically pleasing and then cannot see it's full glory? What's the benefit of that .. :-)

To sum it up - I still believe this is a bug, not a feature. If I choose a font which implements the character then by all means I as an user am fully aware how ugly or unappealing this character may look. Taste is such a subjective matter after all.

I guess we'll have to agree to disagree :) although it is quite sad that in order for me to use a font that I want to I have to compile my own version of libvte.. cheers

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
it's so sad that you are using an argument like 'ugly'. Ugly or Beautiful are very subjective. Again - if you don't like the bricked pattern then you could choose a font which doesn't provide it at all and then be greeted with the shaded block.

I can already see this is a lost cause and again, it is very, very sad that I have to manually compile a custom version of vte just to display a character from the font (that the font provides). This is particularly ironic, given the fact that I cannot display a font character in modern linux desktop environment which I could in a DOS environment which was nowhere near the level of linux. Just out of curiosity, I've also checked qterminal from lxqt as well as terminal in chrome os - both of them display a font-provided glyph.

ok, I promise not to write anything more and you may safely remove this issue. thanks for the explanation. It just looks to me like you're trying to know better than the user what he chooses to see on the screen.

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
Sorry for breaking my promise, but I couldn't resist..

I don't know why you keep referring to the bitmap font. I only asked about bitmap fonts because I thought that vte was ignoring ttf glyph for this particular char, but because vte has an if statement based on a char code, it's irrelevant what font type will I use (bitmap or ttf) because it will ignore the char either way and draw a shaded box. I tried ubuntu mono, monospace and Hacky fonts. To my knowledge, they are true type fonts, with this char implemented (present in the font)

Basically I started all this because I wanted to create a demo which would resemble the look of turbo vision:

![tvision](https://www.jasondl.ee/images/2018/tv_demo.png)

unfortunetely, the bricked pattern is essential to this iconic look and feel and without it, I can't achieve this. I find the bricked pattern particularly appealing, but that is just my subjective taste (though I can understand if you find it ugly). For the time being, my only option is to use one of the terminals I mentioned (rxvt, qterminal, alacritty, etc) or compile my own version of vte. Which is quite frustrating because I use both gnome-terminal and tillix on a regular basis - I like them a lot. I also checked the "regular" tty in linux (ctrl + alt + f2) and it also displays the character.

Once again, sorry for my stubborn attention to detail. To me it's obvious that if a code is not loading a character from a font which provides it it constitues a bug. And yes, if you still prefer to draw it manually then rendering the glyph with pixels would technically still be a bug to me (because it would still not load a glyph from the font) but at least it would definetely be an improvement. However the ideal solution from my end point of view would be just to render the glyph (if the font provides it) and if somebody doesn't like the look of it (as you were kind to point out - the chance of that [that being a typical user seeing this particular glyph] is 1 in a trillion) he could simply change the font to one which doesn't provide the glyph and then vte would render the shaded block. As I mentioned, there are quite few terminals which do display the glyph (yesterday I even checked terminal on Mac OS which also displays it, though I don't have access to any windows machine to check what does it do) and initially I thought that there was something wrong with my code which made the char not appear.

kind regards

events.target_title: question about shaded glyphs / characters

note.body:
I'll try to explain the best I can, although take it with some grain of salt.

actually, first and foremost - I begin to understand why it's impractical to load the glyphs *all the time*. Basically, I created a pattern of lines (constructed of a solid block - 0x2588 IIRC) and displayed it in alacritty and it does show gaps between the glyphs, instead of a solid line. vte displays a solid line so it's definetely better-looking, not going to argue about it.

now, back to Turbo Vision. It is a long abandoned product. as I understand it was only used in DOS-era and it uses extended ascii characters to presend a TUI (Text-user-interface). I think that we can think of it as an old idea of ncurses - you could have multiple windows (all created from text), interact with mouse and resize them, and the windows could be located on top of each other. I have no idea if it was possible to change the font per application in DOS text-based mode, I doubt it. I think that it was possible to change the font for the DOS itself which would then translate to other programs. That's how it was possible to display localized diactric characters - basically the font would replace the characters which the user was unlikely to use on regular basis and I think they called it a codepage. as for the product evolving, I have once heard that Borland created 'Graphics vision' but I think that this was in the days of windows 3.11 era and the product never really took off and Borland has then replaced it with Delphi / C++ Builder suites (which were just calling winAPI under the hood). Again - I'm not much of an expert on this since I stopped using windows ages ago.

It [the text version - turbo vision] has since been ported to linux, I suppose - just for fun. The screenshot I posted is a screenshot of a Java port called jexer, but there is also a linux port called tvision. What I was doing was I was simply trying to write some dummy C code in order to see what does it take to display the iconic bricked background pattern and I got interested why I could not achieve this, which braught me here :)

I can only speculate that the reason why Borland decided to use a bricked character for the canvas / background was to distinguish the background from the "regular" windows which could also be grey. The background seems to be displayed with a blue font on grey background and so if you draw a fully shaded grey window you can tell one from another.

I'm not really sure what I should see at your second screenshot - it looks perfect to me, exactly because there are gaps between the bricks. Although I suppose that without gaps it would look equally nice

events.target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body:
I confirm it fails with other SNI-routing services too. I have peeked into the source code (nm-openconnect-service.c) and it says the following in comments:

```c
/* The actual gateway to use (after redirection) comes from the auth
	   dialog, so it's in the secrets hash not the properties */
```
and later:
```c
/* We just need the WebVPN cookie, and the final IP address of the gateway
   (after HTTP redirects, which do happen). All the certificate/SecurID 
   nonsense can be handled for us, in the user's context, by auth-dialog */
```

It would be great to make it use DNS name instead of IP when passing to the openconnect binary. I recon forcefully passing the value of the "Gateway" field from the connection preferences may break things (in case redirects really happen) but maybe just adding a switch to use name for SNI would be a solution?

events.target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body: I have just checked it and openconnect itself does handle redirects ("Got HTTP response: HTTP/1.0 302 Temporary moved" being returned on console when using openconnect directly and subsequent calls using the new URL) so why not to leave that to openconnect and simply pass the "Gateway" value to it?

events.target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body:
That made me try to find out a way to pass the Gateway value verbatim to openconnect binary. I have made the following change in the code:
```c
--- a/nm-openconnect-service.c	2019-11-27 13:08:38.001128812 +0100
+++ b/nm-openconnect-service.c	2019-11-27 13:08:47.013128355 +0100
@@ -412,7 +412,7 @@
 
 	/* The actual gateway to use (after redirection) comes from the auth
 	   dialog, so it's in the secrets hash not the properties */
-	props_vpn_gw = nm_setting_vpn_get_secret (s_vpn, NM_OPENCONNECT_KEY_GATEWAY);
+	props_vpn_gw = nm_setting_vpn_get_data_item (s_vpn, NM_OPENCONNECT_KEY_GATEWAY);
 	if (!props_vpn_gw || !strlen (props_vpn_gw) ) {
 		g_set_error (error,
 		             NM_VPN_PLUGIN_ERROR,
```
Now I can successfully connect to the VPN server that is behind the SNI-aware proxy. It may possibly break things in a wider sense (I assume there was a reason for how it is implemented today) but it suits my needs for now. And who knows - maybe it was openconnect's fault back then and is no longer needed - and the fix can find its way to the code? ;)

events.target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body:
After investigating it somewhat more I have found that name gets replaced with IP after calling `openconnect_obtain_cookie()` function inside `auth-dialog/main.c` and the function comes from the `/usr/include/openconnect.h` being part of the openconnect itself. Additionally, the `openconnect.h` file contains the following:

```c
/* Returns the IP address of the exact host to which the connection
 * was made. In --cookieonly mode or in any other scenario involving
 * a "two stage" connection, it is important to reconnect by IP because
 * the server side may be using DNS trickery for load balancing.
 *
 * If the IP address is unavailable due to the use of a proxy, this will
 * fall back to returning the DNS name. */
const char *openconnect_get_hostname(struct openconnect_info *);

/* Returns the hostname parsed out of the server name URL. This is
 * intended to be used by the validate_peer_cert callback to check that
 * the certificate matches the server name. */
const char *openconnect_get_dnsname(struct openconnect_info *);
```
So it seems that name -> IP change is intentional on that part. The interesting bit is that when you call openconnect binary directly it does handle it properly (i.e. is SNI-aware/compatible).

The other change that can make the nm-openconnect to work in our case is to modify `auth-dialog/main.c` instead of `nm-openconnect-service.c` (as was suggested in the comment above) and change:

```c
--- a/main.c	2019-11-28 15:30:45.290613991 +0100
+++ b/main.c	2019-11-28 15:31:00.498614939 +0100
@@ -1256,7 +1256,7 @@
 		   by nm-openconnect-service to make the connection */
 		key = g_strdup (NM_OPENCONNECT_KEY_GATEWAY);
 		value = g_strdup_printf ("%s:%d",
-					 openconnect_get_hostname(ui_data->vpninfo),
+					 openconnect_get_dnsname(ui_data->vpninfo),
 					 openconnect_get_port(ui_data->vpninfo));
 		g_hash_table_insert (ui_data->secrets, key, value);
 ```

Again - it may break things as there seems to be a reason to use IP, but seems more 'legit' than the previous hack and does the trick for me.

events.target_title: Vala autocomplete do not work
64-bit memory access alignment issues leading to segfault on sparc64
Avoid potential 64-bit pointer aliasing alignment issues
Make gck attribute value allocation aligned for 64bit systems

note.body:
I'm sorry, I totally missed your merge request here, @psumbera . I submitted a new bug report for the same issue in #34 .
The Debian sparc64 build was running into the same issues as reported by you, and I simply patched it up by replacing the 64-bit memory access with memcpy's in !26 . This is a safe option for any platform and will not even incur a runtime cost on any platform where unaligned 64-bit memory access isn't a problem.

I didn't look into the actual reason why the allocated memory wasn't 64-bit aligned in the first place.
IMHO, it would make sense to assure proper memory alignment to avoid inefficient memory access, but I don't see how this can be done in a safe way with the current implementation. As I understand, the memory referenced by the attributes can be arbitrarily aligned due to packing. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

@dueno already merged !27 , but perhaps we can work out something that optimises memory management to avoid the memcpy call? Simply fixing the allocation will not be enough, as the compiler won't recognise the 'safe' pointers and will still generate a memcpy function call. I don't want to go back to pointer aliasing, as this may still pose a risk in the future if pointer semantics change on one platform.

events.target_title: Make gck attribute value allocation aligned for 64bit systems

note.body:
Possibly, but I'm not sure if this is going to help.
The link to the kernel docs I posted in the other issue ( https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/unaligned-memory-access.txt ) mentions the risk of having packed data structures where members aren't ordered by alignment. In the examples mentioned there however, the compiler will at least be able to figure our when it needs to access memory via an unaligned load/store - or add padding to the data strucutre.
This wasn't the case with gcr, because the serialised data structure is treated like an array of bytes.
Consider what happens when you put bools and ulongs side by side - if the serialisation packs them tightly, then unaligned fields are *always* a possibility.

Example:
```
R=refcount B=bool L=ulong
00 01 02 03 04 05 06 07 08 09 0a 0b 0c 0d 0e 0f 10 11 12
RRRRRRRRRRR BB RRRRRRRRRRR LLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLL
```

I didn't look at how attributes are actually packed by gcr, but this is certainly something to consider.

events.target_title: gnome-shell.css: #panel's "border-radius" only takes first value
Brightness and contrast controls not working: HP Scanjet 5500c

note.body:
I have the same issue with my HP Laser 135a scanner.

The issue is also exists for other scanners:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/simple-scan/+bug/1327801

I investigate this issue, and it occurs when there is no `Sane.NAME_CONTRAST` option_descriptor:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/simple-scan/blob/master/src/scanner.vala#L1139

I investigated why Xsane is working, and it seems that xsane is modifing the output data:
1. First by creating Gamma correction function:
  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_correction#Microsoft_Windows,_Mac,_sRGB_and_TV/video_standard_gammas
  https://github.com/kkaempf/xsane/blob/master/src/xsane-gamma.c#L1322
2. Then applying it to every pixel/channel data:
  https://github.com/kkaempf/xsane/blob/master/src/xsane-scan.c#L250

This method is very efficient, and universal. It allows to enable brightness/contrast manipulation for every device.

@robert.ancell I would like to implement that feature. Do you think such patch could be accepted by simple-scan?

GNOME Shell uses a lot of RAM after heavy use why ??

note.body:
I have the same problem.

- Pop!_OS 19.10 x86_64
- mutter 3.34.1+git20191107-1ubuntu1~19.10.1pop0~1573683812~19.10~50e928a
- gnome-shell 3.34.1-1ubuntu1pop0~1573148724~19.10~f65f9b1

The `gnome-shell` run as the `gdm` user doesn't quit after I have logged in, and it keeps eating up more RAM. My laptop has an NVIDIA GeForce MX150 and Intel UHD Graphics (Whiskey Lake 3x8 GT2), and is capable of hybrid graphics. gnome-shell leaks memory in both hybrid graphics mode and Intel-only mode.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell uses a lot of RAM after heavy use why ??

note.body:
Some people have suggested that buggy GNOME shell extensions may be to blame. So far I have disabled all of the non-default extensions, leaving the default ones that came with Pop!_OS running.

The gdm gnome-shell instance *still* won't quit automatically, and it still keeps eating up more RAM.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell uses a lot of RAM after heavy use why ??

note.body:
@ITwrx There's the `gdm` *process* and then there's the `gdm` *user*.

On my laptop, when I'm logged into a GNOME desktop session, there are two `gnome-shell` processes running: one is run as me, the other is run as the `gdm` user. I'm talking about the `gnome-shell` instance that is run as the `gdm` user. That process is apparently responsible for the login screen, and that's the one that is leaking memory. According to some people on the internet, that `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance is really *not* supposed to keep running after a user has logged into a desktop session, though I cannot speak for the correctness of that claim.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell uses a lot of RAM after heavy use why ??

note.body:
My laptop has both Intel UHD Graphics (Whiskey Lake 3x8 GT2) and an NVIDIA GeForce MX150. And it is possible switch among three graphics modes (restart required):
- hybrid graphics
- intel-only graphics
- nvidia-only graphics

Here are some of the related, installed drivers and packages:

| package or driver | version |
| ------ | ------ |
| i965-va-driver | 2.3.0-0ubuntu2 |
| xserver-xorg-video-intel | 2:2.99.917+git20190815-1 |
| intel-media-va-driver:amd64 | 19.2.1+dfsg1-2ubuntu1 |
| nvidia-driver-440 [*] | 440.31-1pop1~1573485407~19.10~af08493 |
| nvidia-dkms-440 | 440.31-1pop1~1573485407~19.10~af08493 |
| xserver-xorg-video-nvidia-440 | 440.31-1pop1~1573485407~19.10~af08493 |


I have done more testing and here are my discoveries so far:

If I enable nvidia-only graphics:

- The `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance responds to SIGHUP and SIGTERM by respawning, complete with the ibus-related child processes;
- The `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance would immediately use up about 180 MiB RAM right-off-the-bat, and the RAM usage would keep climbing;

If I enable intel-only graphics:

- The `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance responds to SIGHUP (but not SIGTERM) by respawning. The respawned `gnome-shell` instance will *not* have ibus-related child processes;
- The respawned `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance will start at about 39 MiB RAM usage, and pretty much stay there.

[*] The `nvidia-driver-440` metapackage pulls in *a lot* of real, nvidia-related packages, most of which have the exact same version number, so I'm not going to list them all one-by-one.

events.target_title: Borders of edited parts in PDF format
Snap to top and bottom (edges) too

note.body:
@fmuellner it's very true that the auto maximise using the top edge is a super-useful feature, and we shouldn't give it up. However it is also true that screens are becoming bigger and bigger, and it's not so uncommon to have to compare two documents. While code tends to be be compact on the X Axis, and therefore a left-right comparison is pretty handy, that's not the case for anything that is written text, for example written documents, where the X axis is pretty important.

Maybe, from an user-prospective point of view, a proposal could be to have a combination of top edge and press of a shortcut:
- only top edge --> maximise
- top edge + Super --> split half top 

The bottom edge is not used at the moment, IIRC, so that can actually be used as the hint to have the half split.

Regarding shortcut, a proposal would be to have Super + Top Arrow and Super + Right Arrow, to have consistency with the other two.

My two cents.

events.target_title: gtk_window_set_resizable() doesn't works
gtk_window_set_resizable() doesn't works
gtk_window_set_resizable() doesn't works
Allow layer boundaries to be adjusted automatically

note.body:
I and many other people I know switched from GIMP to Photoshop as soon as they could afford it primarily because this issue is too disruptive to workflow (brush options were the other factor but that has mostly been resolved). It seems like many people don't post about this because they assume that such an important feature can't be that far away, but this issue was reported 17 years ago and is still not a feature. This is why after 16 years of trying GIMP roughly once a year, I am speaking up. I can't stress enough the importance of this feature so please, if anyone reading this has any influence on development priorities, please make this feature a higher priority. In my opinion it by far the most important thing on the roadmap. 

For cases where specific layer sizes are desirable my suggestion is to have a "Lock layer size" checkbox (in the layer properties dialogue) that disables dynamic resizing an enables the layer dimension inputs. The default behaviour for new layers could be a document or program setting, which may be useful for animation projects.

events.target_title: Can't delete TIF files that Gimp 2.10.12 has exported.

note.body:
I have encountered this issue as well.

Gimp 2.10.14 from gimp.org
Windows 10 64-bit

I have tried the following to delete/alter the files (after both a restart and a cold reboot):
* Normal delete (to recycle bin)
* Force delete
* Normal delete in safe mode
* Force delete in safe mode
* Rename in normal and safe mode
* Rename the parent directory in normal and safe mode

All these attempts failed silently. Rename attempts cause File Explorer to hang.

Reopening the file in Gimp works fine.
Attempting to use the file in Scribus 1.4.8 shows an image with many layers missing (which may be a Scribus issue).
Using IrfanView 4.37 to view the file shows a black image (maybe it doesn't support multilayer tiffs).

I've used Microsoft's Process Explorer to check for hanging file locks. There are none, although the files very much act like they are locked.

I've turned off thumbnail generation in Windows and deleted all thumbs.db files using the Windows Drive Cleanup tool. No dice.

events.target_title: window titlebar buttons placed left causes flickering text and non responsive buttons

note.body:
It seems to be caused by https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-tweaks/commit/6ecb055b1c2cf75f517ee8a81fc57d9fbb487637
I have tried fixing it myself but without much success.

I can somewhat workaround it with:
```
diff --git a/gtweak/tweakview.py b/gtweak/tweakview.py
index 5de11d6..515d0f1 100644
--- a/gtweak/tweakview.py
+++ b/gtweak/tweakview.py
@@ -16,7 +16,7 @@ class Window(Gtk.ApplicationWindow):
         Gtk.ApplicationWindow.__init__(self,
                                        application=app,
                                        show_menubar=False)
-        self.set_size_request(-1, 700)
+        self.set_size_request(950, 700)
         self.set_position(Gtk.WindowPosition.CENTER)
         self.set_icon_name("org.gnome.tweaks")
 
@@ -168,7 +168,6 @@ class Window(Gtk.ApplicationWindow):
 
     def main_content(self):
         right_box = Gtk.Box(orientation=Gtk.Orientation.VERTICAL)
-        right_box.set_size_request(750, -1)
 
         self.stack = Gtk.Stack()
         self.stack.get_style_context().add_class("main-container")

```
but that defeats the purpose of the change linked above as we won't be able to go below 950x700 anymore, it also exposes yet another regression introduced by the change — switching buttons from left -> right leaves an empty space until the window is redrawn? (eg. resized).

note.body:
Hello Jerome

Thank you for your very prompt response! Yes, I certainly did install
Libinsane. Now I must admit I embarrassingly recall I didn't install it
first but after I'd installed Paperwork. Yes, I probably should have
installed Libsane first but I probably missed it initially. I certainly
didn't do anything (like try and open Paperwork) before it was installed,
and I followed the commands on your very informative web-page - viz:

sudo apt install make meson gtk-doc-tools doxygen plantuml graphviz

events.target_title: Add way to change audio output (speakers vs headphones) on a per application basis
Add way to change audio output (speakers vs headphones) on a per application basis

note.body:
The extension doesn't provide the functionality in question, I just used it as an idea for design. Sorry for the misunderstanding. 

But even if an extension provided the functionality, extensions are not officially supported and the API is not stable. Relying on a third party, that isn't guaranteed to work between versions, for providing basic functionality is bad design in my opinion.

I'm not saying that extensions should be incorporated into shell as they have their use: customization (e.g. Dash to Dock/Panel) or special configurations (themes, distros such ZorinOS that make gnome more Windows-like) are valid reasons to use extensions. However, using two audio sources concurrently doesn't seem to me like something _that_ special. That's why other DEs provide the functionality built-in through an applet or in settings (I have first-hand experience with Plasma and Windows, can't say for others)

EDIT: grammar

events.target_title: gnome-session should not save/restore RequiredComponents (causes upgrade failure when switching to systemd startup)

note.body:
>  It turns out that users can still enable session auto-saving

Isn't implementing the XSM Protocol a core task of gnome-session?

[man page gnome-session(1)](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-session/blob/master/doc/man/gnome-session.1#L29) here in the repository says so:
`\fIgnome-session\fP is an X11R6 session manager. It can manage GNOME applications as well as any X11R6 SM compliant application.`


The first link in the "Links" section on [https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/SessionManagement](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/SessionManagement) is to [More Than You Ever Wanted To Know About XSMP](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/SessionManagement/NotesOnXSMP) on Gnome wiki by Dan Winship.

The X11R7.7 XSM Protocol specification [https://www.x.org/releases/X11R7.7/doc/libSM/xsmp.html] is not tied to an X server:
>  There was much discussion over whether the XSMP protocol should use X as the transport protocol or whether it should use its own independent transport. It was decided that it would use an independent protocol for several reasons. First, the Session Manager should be able to manage programs that do not maintain an X connection.

The functionality provided by XSM remains useful under wayland and systemd.
 
2 days ago on a laptop I was installing Debian sid on, I wanted to disable some autostart services (the a11y background services), and noticed the news announced here: https://blogs.gnome.org/benzea/2019/10/01/gnome-3-34-is-now-managed-using-systemd/ .
I failed to find a design document driving this ongoing effort. Looking for that I found this issue, and I now am doubting there is any such a document, I am afraid there is no clear direction.

Specifically, I discovered the new `X-GNOME-HiddenUnderSystemd=true` entry in the .desktop files in `/etc/xdg/autostart`. I found it in the comment in the blog post. I also noticed that similar functionality is provided in the .service files for D-Bus activation (eg: /usr/share/dbus-1/services/org/a11y.Bus.service), by the `SystemdService=` key (Documentation: search "SystemdService" in https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-daemon.1.html and https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-specification.html ).
  Then I reviewed the [freedesktop.org Desktop Application Autostart Specification]( https://specifications.freedesktop.org/autostart-spec/0.5/index.html) and wondered what is the difference between a spec compliant `NotShowIn=GNOME` and a custom `X-GNOME-HiddenUnderSystemd=true` (apart from compatibility with downgrading of gnome-session package).
The I came to this issue to write this comment.

Without any intention to be abrasive, these above are my doubts. They are summarized by: is the session save and restore functionality going down the drain without alternatives?

Now my 2 cents. 
I wonder if implementing a systemd generator to convert the .desktop files in /etc/xdg/autostart would be any better:
*  it could easily handle the .desktop files from ~/.config/gnome-session/saved-session/  both the obsolete ones this issue is about AND the good ones from a good previous saved session.
* With a generator, only the management of the processes would be handed over to systemd in the form of unit files,
* while the management of the session in the XSM meaning would stay untouched, implemented by the .desktop files.
* The applicable existing specifications (XSM, XDG Autostart) would stay relevant and would guide the development.

Regards,

Marco Gamberoni

events.target_title: Parse natural language

note.body:
Didn't this issue went a little too far?.. It would be great add events to the calendar without being forced to edit them right after the creation just to add the hour. It sounds to me like a super common use case - I mean, doesn't most of our events last less than a day? And why would NLP be required to merely allow input such as "4pm Dinner" "4h30 Dinner" and "16:00 Dinner". Wouldn't this be possible if we make it a little simpler, and it will still be tremendously useful?

Would you accept such a thing (again, no NLP, just a time parser) as PR?

events.target_title: GtkFileChooserDialog Unexpectedly Overwrites Another File
mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection
mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body:
Thanks for your comment.

With the ucm, the pulseaudio will put [In] or [Out] prefix in the port name, that is different from the names without ucm. So we couldn't change the port names in the ucm to make them be same as the ones without ucm.

Because only Dell laptops have multi-function audio jacks, we (Intel, Dell and Canonical) tested this change on different Dell laptops, include old laptops (without ucm) and recently released laptops (with ucm): Inspiron5490 Inspiron5590 Vostro5490 Vostro5590 Inspiron3590

We applied this patch to the gnome-settings-daemon, then built the whole gnome-settings-daemon, after that we ran gsd-media-keys, after we plug something in the audio jack, the pop-up dialogue will show, we could select the headphones, headset-mic or headphone-mic from the dialogue, after selecting, we could open the gnome-sound-setting to check, all audio function worked well.

Without this patch, if we plug something in the audio jack on the machines which use the ucm, the pop-up dialogue will not show up.

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body:
This is the original design of pulseaudio, the naming rule for ucm ports was introduced by this patch: https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/pulseaudio/pulseaudio/commit/c19d1082192312bdc8fb8f8a462e2e6843efc9b6

The ucm ports and non-ucm ports have different naming rule in the pulseaudio, that exists for a long time. In the past, the ucm is used for embedded systems which have I2S codec, while the non-ucm is used for PC or laptops which have HDA codec, so the different naming rule didn't introduce any trouble. Now intel introduces the new audio driver sof which is used for HDA codec+DMIC on PCH, Intel decides to use ucm+pulseaudio. To support ucm audio functions under gnome, I wrote this patch.

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body: Those names are not constant, it partly depends on the ucm, it partly depends on pulseaudio itself. For example, users put Speakers in the ucm, the finial port name is "[Out] Speakers", if users put spk in the ucm, the finial port name is "[Out] spk". Intel already finished the ucm, According to that ucm, I wrote those port names in my patch.

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body: The only possible solution is doing the change in the pulseaudio (removing those [In] and [Out] prefixes), but if we really change pulseaudio, it will affect many many existing apps because they already uses [In]/[Out] in their code for many years.

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body: Sorry, I don't know what apps will be affected. In theory, it has possibility to affect the existing apps since this naming rule exists for many years.

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body:
It doesn't mean if users put new names in the ucm, they will submit new patches to libgnome-volume-control.

Intel already set the names in the ucm for the machines with multi-function audio jack, and those names will be fixed. so the libgnome-volume-control only needs to maintain two set of names, one is for non-ucm ports, the other is for ucm ports.

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body:
This is the ucm1 released to Canonical for ubuntu 18.04 by Intel (https://github.com/thesofproject/alsa-ucm-conf, branch sof_ucm1, commit 78b7842.).

It is good that we will have ucm2 and have the standard name for those ports, if those port names could be merged to libgvc, I will backport the patch to ubuntu 18.04 (changing the name from ucm2 to ucm1).

Thanks.
Hui.

events.target_title: Translation the visa application process in English

note.body:
Countries and regions that require visa to travel to México

Valid since november 9 of 2012

People with nationalities of the following countries or regions have to obtain a visa to travel to México. For recreation, business or any type of non-paid activity in México that does not exceed 180 days, they will have to apply in a mexican council for the visitant Visa without permit to perform paid activities.

The foreign that presents any of the following documents will NOT have to apply for a visa:

a) Document that accredits a permanent residence in Canada, United States of America, Japan, United Kingdom of Great Britan and North Ireland, any of th countries that integrate the Schengen Area, and those countries that are members of the Pacific Alliance(Chile, Colombia and Peru).

b) Valid and active visa for Canada, United States of America, Japan, United Kingdom of Great Britan and North Ireland, any of th countries that integrate the Schengen Area.

c) Business Travelers Card from APEC (ABTC) approved by México.

d) Certificate that vailidates the person as a crew member of the plane in wich they arrive.

e) Seaman's Book, if the person is a crew member of the boat that arrives in a mexican port. in a international traversy. If the crew member arrives airway to enroll in a ship in a national port, besides the seaman's book, they need to present the document that validates their enrollment, information about the ship and mexican port in wich it is currently in.

events.target_title: First export to PDF resets image print definition

note.body:
Actually, the bug is not always reproducible, as can be seen on the initial question's comments on Graphic Design Stack Exchange. It happens on Manjaro KDE 18.1.3, but does not happen on Windows 10.

Also, reproduction steps as listed above are incorrect :
1. `File` => `New` and create an `A4 (300 ppi)` image using the `Template` drop down menu
2. Modify the image in any way (the image ***has*** to be modified)
3. `File` => `Export` as and export as PDF (***without*** opening the `Image` => `Print size` dialogue window and changing the ppi)

Expected :

4. The generated PDF properties should show a `Page size` of `210 x 297 mm (Portrait A4)`

Actual :

4. The generated PDF properties show a `Page size` of `875 x 1238 mm (Portrait Custom)`

Work around :

Before exporting, go to `Image` => `Print size` and change the ppi value to 300.

events.target_title: Kerberos: temporary accounts not cleaned up, spams journal at crazy high rate

note.body:
The workaround posted by brianmercer resolved the issue on RHEL 7.5 modifying the .service files. For anyone else that stumbles upon this, the location is slightly different on Red Hat, /usr/share/dbus-1/services/ : 


```
/usr/share/dbus-1/services/org.gnome.Identity.service

[D-BUS Service]
Name=org.gnome.Identity
Exec=/bin/false
 
and 
 
/usr/share/dbus-1/services/org.gnome.OnlineAccounts.service

[D-BUS Service]
Name=org.gnome.OnlineAccounts
Exec=/bin/false

reboot
```

Thanks for your help! No longer have to deal with the messages log being spammed with thousands of errors a minute.

events.target_title: Consistently crashes on Passwords > Login keyring

note.body:
If this helps, I can prevent it from crashing if I use GTK_DEBUG=no-pixel-cache OR GDK_RENDERING=recording with some caveats.

GDK_RENDERING=recording works but has lots of rendering artifacts.
GDK_RENDERING=image does not crash but Passwords/Login does not render.  Certificates/Secure Shell/PGP Keys render fine.

If I use GTK_DEBUG=no-pixel-cache everything seems to work properly.

I agree with the above that it seems related to the number of passwords in the Login store.  I have 716 secrets stored in Login at the moment.

Update:  I went through my keystore and deleted a bunch of old junk.  seahorse started working again without GTK_DEBUG=no-pixel-cache somewhere between 545-538 passwords stored.  I was expecting it to fail until I got to 512 but that doesn't seem to be the case.  I would guess it has to do more with the total amount of information stored rather than the actual count of passwords.

Update 2: I see the file size of the keyring with 538 passwords is 1307914k.  I didn't check the size beforehand.

note.body:
Oh, I wasn't aware that there are 2 themes menus in the settings. Changing the icon theme does the job.

Anyway, I consider this a bug in 2 respects:
1) When upgrading Gimp from a version with colorful icons, the icon theme should default to either the "Color" or the "Legacy" theme, not the so-called "Symbolic" theme.
2) The "Symbolic" theme is unusable (see screenshot) and should be fixed.

events.target_title: toolbox icons lost their colors

note.body: @prokoudine: It seems that you had not read my second comment, because we were posting almost at the same time. For me personally, the problem is solved (I now know the workaround), but for thousands of other users it is not. Today I checked an installation on another PC where Gimp was installed a few weeks ago (fresh install, no upgrade), and it had the same problem. That means that Gimp activates a broken theme by default, and all Gimp users (new users as well as upgraders) are affected.

events.target_title: toolbox icons lost their colors
toolbox icons lost their colors

note.body: Please don't repeat closing a bug that has not been fixed yet. How can you claim that the default theme is not broken when my screenshot proves it is? And what do you mean by "the packager"? One of my two installations is on a Windows system, with the binary installer directly downloaded from www.gimp.org. The other installation is from the FreeBSD port which simply installs what comes with the source tarball from one of the Gimp mirrors. The FreeBSD installer does not fiddle with the themes.

events.target_title: toolbox icons lost their colors
toolbox icons lost their colors

note.body:
The screenshot is from FreeBSD, but in Windows it looked the same except for the window decoration. You can easily reproduce it by doing a fresh install (unless it has been fixed in 2.10.14, which I haven't tested yet).

You can browse the FreeBSD port at https://svnweb.freebsd.org/ports/head/graphics/gimp-app/ and see that nobody made it load a certain theme. The port is just a framework to install what's in the source tarball.

Apart from that, default themes should be ignored when upgrading Gimp and an existing config is found. I have been using Gimp for years on my FreeBSD box. There are directories called $HOME/.gimp-2.4, $HOME/.gimp-2.6 and $HOME/.gimp-2.8. (Where .gimp-2.10 has gone, I don't know.) When gimp 2.10 first starts, it should read the settings from $HOME/.gimp-2.8 and use the same settings, or settings as close as possible, in the new version. That is, if the old version had colored icons, the new version should, of course, also use colored icons, even if the default for a fresh install would be grayscale icons.

events.target_title: Give/record helpful feedback if a drag & drop action fails
Give/record helpful feedback if a drag & drop action fails

note.body:
I'm afraid I don't understand enough about the working of Nautilus to know what information is made available between it and application XYZ when dragging and dropping, sorry.

I assumed it's enough to tell Nautilus the operation worked (leading to the icon disappearing over its destination) or it didn't (leading to the icon animating its returning to the Nautilus window). I hadn't considered this might be managed by something else entirely instead.

I'd hoped (naively) whatever detected these two states also received information from app XYZ in the event of an unsuccessful drop, and Nautilus might record/present that somehow. In hindsight I appreciate the responsibility for reporting a drop failure could also fall to XYZ as the destination; I thought the metaphor of dragging something *from* Nautilus *to* XYZ lent itself to logging some sort of "Nautilus couldn't do that because [x]."

events.target_title: Give/record helpful feedback if a drag & drop action fails

note.body:
That's very true. The animation makes very clear that the drop failed, yes; though in cases where this behaviour is unexpected (e.g. "It worked before, why doesn't it work now?"), the animation alone provides no context about why the drop failed.

I completely agree for cases where "We don't know anything else" is the full extent of Nautilus' understanding, another dialog to click away would be useless and annoying clutter. I'd hoped the other windows already provided information on why a drop wasn't accepted, such that Nautilus could know more and log it. If that information isn't provided, either by the other window or whatever application handles the dragging and dropping, I'm not sure how unexpected changes in drag-and-drop behaviour might be investigated further.

For example, I used to be able to drag a .png into GIMP to add it as a new layer. Recently, GIMP is now refusing the drop. Is there any information during the dragging-and-dropping process which could be logged to help investigate what's causing such behaviour? If not, is it feasible there could be?

Trial and error seems to indicate my case was caused by a mutter update, but it would have been great to have an error message logged somewhere which could have narrowed my searching online.

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body:
Perhaps, it might be nice to have abstraction aliases (links, additional names) for PA ports so the apps can select the port according the functionality. So, for UCM the implementation in PA might be: 
analog-input-internal-mic -> [In] InternalMic
analog-input-internal-mic -> [In] DigitalMic
analog-input-internal-mic -> [In] Mic
The first present UCM device with the highest priority will win. Also, unrelated, the current gvc-mixer-control code sets analog-output-headphones for both GVC_HEADSET_PORT_CHOICE_HEADPHONES and GVC_HEADSET_PORT_CHOICE_HEADSET. This mapping should be also hidden in PA, I think. The things are worse when I look to the UCM device names for some old Intel hardware. We are too much benevolent and we need to resolve this in UCM, too. I'm talking about something like "IN1-InternalMics".

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body: Thinking more, I can add this functionality identificator to UCM device defitions, too. So the apps can group the UCM devices by the functionality and priority and choose the right one. Let me know, if you think that it's a good idea to have this description at one place (UCM).

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body:
Thinking more about this today, we should be probably more strict for names in UCM. The name should express the expected functionality, too.

https://github.com/alsa-project/alsa-lib/blob/5473c5d677915b88d5c93d5bcc6cd16bb6a40342/include/use-case.h#L124-L134

From the user perspective, microphone is just microphone. It does not matter, if it's analog or digital (the "visible" functionality is same). Thus names like "Dmic" or "DigitalMic" are something extra beyond a convention which we want to define. We can show this extra description using the device's comment.

I was thinking also about HeadsetMic / HeadphonesMic and I'd like to remove those names, too. The Headphones/Headset devices in UCM may be bidirectional (input + output), thus we don't need extra names for single directions.

So I just propose to follow the original names with the numbers extension (for the multiple devices like HDMI). Check the URL above, please.

I plan to write an UCM validator to check and fix all those non-standard UCM configurations.

CVS revived

note.body:
It is brilliant you have revived CVS support, many thanks. We are still using cvs at my workplace. However, we are specifically using `cvs` rather than `cvsnt` on our Linux machines where the last release was 1.11.x which unfortunately doesn't support the `cvs ls` command you've used in `valid_repo()`. I'm not sure what sensible alternate command should be used but I would like to try and fix this.

EDIT:
We could just use something similar to the [old version](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/meld/commit/57e936584ffb0104ac715cb587aeae6d9d0c0f26#693eed7bffa2831a5eb7c3a012fdd231583b82d4_75_0):
```
 def valid_repo(cls, path):
        return os.path.exists(os.path.join(path, cls.VC_DIR, "Entries"))

```

events.target_title: CVS revived

note.body:
Thanks for the reply. Well, that is embarrassing. I only looked at the news page and the `stable` source directory, both of which are very old. Apologies.

I did actually get a bit further after hacking that function and I hit another problem where the list of files to `status` was so long that it exceeded the maximum command length. It looks like you are walking the filesystem and collecting every non-CVS file you see rather than interrogating the entries files. We have an already very large repository, that is also full of build artifacts (I know...), so there's an enormous number of files in our cvsroot directory and most of them are irrelevant. I'm thinking that even once I split the status operation up into smaller chunks, it's going to run incredibly slowly. What do you think? Roughly what size repository do you work with? Do you have any non-source controlled files under your cvsroot directory? With our in-house cvs tooling we've always had to use the various entries files to get around these issues.

note.body: Yeh ok, that makes sense. I appreciate you don't want to get into that mess. But if nothing else, it's worth noting for anyone else that finds themselves here, depending on your repository size and structure this might be unusable as is. Thanks for all your work anyway, it is appreciated.

events.target_title: Gimp 2.10 crashing on Lubuntu

note.body:
Setting `export SWT_GTK3=0` in  `/etc/bash.bashrc` forces GTK2 and fixes several application stability issues in Lubuntu.

Qt was deliberately designed to replace GTK3. Lubuntu ships with Qt-based LXDE, but has GTK3 enabled by default - possibly inherited from Debian.

events.target_title: window focus change lags, some keystrokes go to the wrong (old) window

note.body:
This is driving me nuts as well. I find about half the time I switch focus I accidentally type into the wrong window.

The gsetting command above has no effect however :(

events.target_title: window focus change lags, some keystrokes go to the wrong (old) window

note.body:
It looks like this is what's needed now to get responsive focus:
```
gsettings set org.gnome.shell.extensions.classic-overrides focus-change-on-pointer-rest false
```
It's astonishing how much of a difference this makes. The whole UI feels snappier when you get instantaneous feedback from common operations and moving the mouse is sadly one of the commonest. Inserting a noticeable lag to responding to mouse movements made the whole desktop feel like molasses.

A lot of the misdirected keystrokes I had were copy and pastes where I was trying to copy and paste between windows. Or where I was just trying to hit enter in the a terminal on a command that was already typed. I don't think waiting until the mouse stops moving is really a workable solution to this problem. I think you have to rethink the idea of having menus for a one window be in a separate window in a different part of the desktop such that users need to move the mouse across large distances and unrelated windows to access. That's fundamentally a broken design.

If you do want to have that perhaps you can make this menu bar have a delay or something, but please don't change the global focus behaviour just so that this menu bar does what you're looking for. I think that's the kind of thing the expression "the tail wagging the dog" was made for.

events.target_title: window focus change lags, some keystrokes go to the wrong (old) window

note.body:
Incidentally a side effect is that the response to moving the mouse is now actually *accurate*. That is, now windows are decorated and things are coloured based on where the keystrokes are actually going to be delivered. Previously there was a window of time when desktop windows were telling me they were active and would receive keystrokes but actually by the time I pressed a key that might or might not still be true.

Responsive UIs that give users accurate and reliable feedback on what the results of their actions will be are soooo much easier to use....

I think the "classic-overrides" confusion comes from https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=786496 somehow. Apparently we have overrides for overrides now :)

But that might be why some versions one is the right setting, and on other versions the other. And it may depend on whether your distribution sets an override or not.

note.body: I think the best way to handle this is to clear the default font_map so that it can be re-imported when/if it is needed. That should add minimal overhead. I have opened an issue with pangocairo to see if there is a good way to handle this: https://github.com/gtk-rs/pangocairo/issues/60. Thoughts?

events.target_title: text rendering requires restart to detect new fonts

note.body:
@federico I'm stuck and could use some pointers. I'm trying call functions from pango_cairo_sys directly for now, but I can't seem to be able to access the package. I just get

```
7 | use pango_cairo_sys;
  |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ no `pango_cairo_sys` external crate
```

Are there additional steps I need to take to be able to use this package (pangocairo-sys). I have added it to dependencies in Cargo.toml

```
[dependencies]
bitflags = "1.0"
cairo-rs = { version="0.7.0", features=["v1_16"] }
cairo-sys-rs = "0.9.0"
pangocairo-sys = "0.10.0"
```

ran
```
cargo build
```

Feels like I'm missing something.

The goal is to run 
```rust
unsafe {
        pango_cairo_sys::pango_cairo_font_map_set_default(ptr::null_mut());
}
```
or something like that. Do I need to cast null_mut?

events.target_title: text rendering requires restart to detect new fonts

note.body:
Ok, thanks. That's a lot of resources and helps clarify how other apps handle this.

So, setting the default font map to null with `pango_cairo_font_map_set_default` should force it to get a new version next time it goes to retrieve the default fontmap. So far I have added that to render_cairo_sub and I am currently working on loading a fresh version of the fontmap with fontconfig.

events.target_title: text rendering requires restart to detect new fonts

note.body:
Doesn't seem like just clearing the default and forcing a new version to be created is doing the trick for us.

I also tried the `pango::FontMapExt::changed(&font_map);` method which ends up calling `pango_fc_font_map_changed` (an apparent red herring for `pango_fc_font_map_config_changed`) which does a whole lot of nothing:

https://github.com/GNOME/pango/blob/mainline/pango/pangofc-fontmap.c#L2001

If I can get hold of someone with understanding of pango that can explain to me if there is or is not a higher level function like change that actually calls pango_fc_font_map_config_changed or why change doesn't call it, that might be the place to fix it. 

Alternatively, why nulling the default config is not reloading the cache:

```
unsafe {
        pango_cairo_sys::pango_cairo_font_map_set_default(ptr::null_mut());
    }
```

Doesn't seem to do anything even though it causes a new font_map to be created on the next call to get_default().

events.target_title: pangocairo clear font cache
pangocairo clear font cache

note.body: Ok, I added that call to the gir, regenerated and am now calling it, but it doesn't seem to do anything. Is fontconfig doing some caching as well. Even after running `fc-cache -rv`, then calling `pango_fc_font_map_config_changed` and `pango_fc_font_map_cache_clear` for good measure I'm still left with a stale cache. Application restart fixes still required. Maybe exposing `pango_fc_font_map_get_config ()` and `pango_fc_font_map_set_config ()` and then somehow using fontconfig to really flush the cache is what it takes. Or maybe it is not enough to flush the cache on a os-level, it needs to be flushed in the app as well?

events.target_title: pangocairo clear font cache

note.body:
Digging a little deeper I'm seeing that the font_map fini and init functions are clearing the local queues, but they don't touch the FcConfig object stored in `fcfontmap->priv->config`. Although, I don't quite understand the macro magic happening here in `font_map_init`:
```
priv = fcfontmap->priv = pango_fc_font_map_get_instance_private (fcfontmap);
```
Is it just getting a cached private instance? That would explain why clearing the font_map cache does nothing.

fini, inint:
https://github.com/GNOME/pango/blob/mainline/pango/pangofc-fontmap.c#L1171

Evince "save as" reports error and ignores default protection acl

note.body:
Hi.

I am still seeing this problem in Evince 3.18.2-1 in Ubuntu 16 and 3.28.4 on Ubuntu 18.

Steps to reproduce the problem:
```console
$ mkdir test
$ cd test/
$ chgrp www-data .
$ chmod g+w
$ chmod g+s
$ setfacl -dm u::rwx,g::rwx,o::r  .
$ mkdir test
$ cd test/
$ chgrp www-data .
$ chmod g+w
$ chmod g+s
$ setfacl -dm u::rwx,g::rwx,o::r  .
```

Then, save file from gedit, and check permissions:
```console
-rw-rw-r--   1 administrador www-data         10 dic  5 13:07 gedit_file
```

Now, save file from Evince, and check:
```console
-rw-------   1 administrador administrador 39952 dic  4 12:52 evince_file.pdf
```

note.body:
Hi @kaiw , the change of `libintl` cannot make translations work because we haven't make po files built to mo for Windows target and there might be some problems within.

However, it should resolve issue #380 . I encounter the same warning as in #380 and as I found in mingw_w64 from msys2,  there is no module of `intl.dll` but directly `libintl-8.dll`. So the solution is fallback to `libintl-8.dll`.

events.target_title: Gimp freezes on every attempt to Export

note.body:
I have a similar issue. I'm running OSx 10.13.6. I have reproduced this bug on every version of Gimp 2.10.x but I currently have Gimp 2.10.14 installed.  When you try to export and also when you try to do some other activities like use the file picker, Gimp freezes up. You get the spinning color wheel and it shows in the activity monitor that Gimp is not responding. If I revert back to the last version of Gimp 2.8, the issue disappears. 

As I was playing with this last night, I noticed a few things. I was testing just by dragging and dropping a .png image and then trying to export it without any editing. At some point, I decided to try some different images, and realized that the bug disappears when uploading certain other images (both .png and .svg). Very weird. I then just tried adding some text and exporting it and I still experienced the same bug.

This morning, as I was trying to reproduce the bug on Gimp 2.10.14 for the purpose of capturing the verbose output, I realized that Gimp does actually recover from this. On some exports it has recovered in as quickly as 20 seconds. On file picking actions I have clocked times of around 3 minutes. 


I am posting the verbose output below of the following actions:

1) I ran  /Applications/Gimp-2.10.app/Contents/MacOS/gimp --verbose --console-messages from terminal

2) I selected "open" from file menu and opened my downloads folder from the file picker. When I selected the download folder and clicked open, Gimp froze for 2mins 48seconds.

3) I then selected a .png image and it opened and displayed on the canvas immediately.

4) I used the paintbrush tool to draw a line on the image. 

5) I selected "export as" from the file menu and Gimp froze again for 1min 17seconds.  

6) From there I was able to rename the file and export it successfully. 


(P.S. I also attached a screenshot of the output containing highlighted errors below the following code.)

events.target_title: Overlapping OCG layers don't respond to clicks
Archive conversations shortcut is difficult to remember and perform

note.body:
It'd be ideal if the "keyboard shortcuts" window just let users modify the keybindings... I'm used to the Thunderbird setting that makes the "Delete" key function as an archive key. Or perhaps it already does, and I can't figure out how?

Thanks for all your hard work on the Geary project,

Ryan

events.target_title: Evolution 3.34.2 flatpak mail setting "browser-close-on-delete-or-junk" not working?
Evolution 3.34.2 flatpak mail setting "browser-close-on-delete-or-junk" not working?

note.body:
I've solved the problem. According to https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=794832 and https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=220999#c19, the command to set the option was

```gsettings set org.gnome.evolution.mail browser-close-on-delete-or-junk true```

When I run that, I receive a `No such schema “org.gnome.evolution.mail”` message.  If I instead run

```dconf write /org/gnome/evolution/mail/browser-close-on-delete-or-junk true```

the application behaves as expected.

events.target_title: shell: Allow to set the date during import

note.body:
I failed to reproduce your issue. Maybe I didn't understand your problem, could you provide sample commands that illustrate the wrong behaviour?

Here is what I tried (assuming I have document1.pdf and document2.pdf in my current directory):

__Case 1__: imports both documents by setting the id to the current date, the second one gets `_1` appended, but their names are identical
```
paperwork-shell import document*.pdf
```


__Case 2__: fails to import on of the document because of concurrency problems
```
paperwork-shell import document1.pdf & paperwork-shell import document2.pdf
```


__Case 3__: imports both documents as `20191207`, the second one gets `_1` appended
```
paperwork-shell import document1.pdf -- --name 20191207
paperwork-shell import document2.pdf -- --name 20191207
```

events.target_title: Allow creation of event with start and end in different timezones

note.body:
I didn't look in bugzilla. I did look for anything similar in the Gnome issue database: I found several issues relating to Evolution having problems importing an ical file with different time zones for the start and end of an event. I think this is a different issue: I don't care how the event is represented internally or in an exported or imported ical file. I do want to be able to interactively create an event by specifying start and end times in different time zones.
One possible way of enabling this would be to switch (or make user configurable or a popup query) the way that Evolution behaves if I change the time zone after I have input a time. Currently it leaves the displayed time the same (which changes the meaning in UTC). I would like to be able to preserve the UTC time (which would change the displayed time).
An alternative would be to move the time zone to the right of the time rather than below it and have separate time zones for start and end. This needs a reasonably wide window.

I'm not sure what you meant here, so will describe what I did:
- I imported an `.ovpn` config file in `NetworkManager`, and used the default configuration for the credentials.
- I used `nm-connection-editor` -> my Wifi network -> `General` -> `VPN auto-connect` -> My VPN connection
- reboot

I think is it linked to another issue I have: ATM `NetworkManager` is unable to remember the VPN password.

Even if i use the default configuration `store the password for this user only`, trying to activate the VPN will simply prompt me again for the password.
Also opening the connection settings will reveal that the password has never been saved.


If you have more questions, feel free.



Thanks.

events.target_title: Peer DNS Does not work with OpenFortiVPN 1.11

note.body:
Actually, the issue is that --no-dns is passed to openfortivpn and the default in earlier versions was pppd-use-peerdns = 1, which caused that pppd took care about the nameserver update. It was a long standing issue that openfortivpn and pppd were competing about the task to update resolv.conf. Now that we have finally found the root cause why set-dns didn't work independently from pppd, we could change the defaults. 
The only thing we didn't expect was that the network manager plugin explicitly adds --no-dns when it expects that the dns servers are updated in resolv.conf

events.target_title: Peer DNS Does not work with OpenFortiVPN 1.11

note.body:
I should have added that the more compatible change would be to add --use-peer-dns=1 to the options. That works with older versions of openfortivpn and it restores the previous behavior for the 1.11 version. 
However, a drawback is that pppd doesn't recieve the dns suffix which is added as a domain search entry in resolv.conf.
On the current master we also have support for [resolvconf](http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/trusty/man8/resolvconf.8.html). which also works with the built-in mechanism to update the nameservers.
Of course pppd can call resolvconf out of its ip-up-script, too, but again, this can only update the nameservers and not the domain search path.

note.body:
Issue is 100% reproducible. I am using Ubuntu 19.10 (but didn't work with recent previous Ubuntu versions either, as noted) and package manager suggests gvfs package version (and that of all other packages with name containing gvfs) is `1.42.1-1ubuntu1`

OK, I'm assuming that someone can configure a Linux server computer to make directories available via the SMB protocol (Samba).

On the client at the shell prompt

`gio mount smb://user@host/share`

where user, host and share are replaced by the appropriate values - and you enter the correct password when prompted.

This always works fine. Has worked for some time and works now.

Now launch nautilus. The mounted share shows on the left hand pane. (Good)

Single click the share. The top level directories of the share are listed in the right hand pane. (Good)

On the right hand pane navigate to a directory that contains a range of .txt files (work with me). In order that you and I can guarantee to have the same files I am going to use RFCs, which you can access by searching by RFC number here: https://www.rfc-editor.org/search/rfc_search.php

choose the ASCII version and then save as a .txt files in your share. Once you have downloaded them:

Double click the file for RFC 0792. Works fine. gedit opens and I am looking at the specification for ICMP.

Double click the file for RFC 0793 and you get the previously mentioned error from gedit
`Unexpected error: Software caused connection abort`
Expected outcome is that I am looking at the specification for TCP.

Now single click the file for RFC 0792 and press CTRL/C and then press CTRL/V

Gives error dialog `Software caused connection abort` so click Cancel
Expected outcome is no error message.

Now press F5 and you can see that the copy seems to have worked.

events.target_title: Software caused connection abort, with Ubuntu

note.body:
If launching gedit from the command line as e.g.

gedit smb://user@host/share/path/file.txt

where file.txt is that of RFC 0793 then in addition to the usual message, the following message is output to the terminal

`** (org.gnome.gedit:22057): WARNING **: 20:47:06.972: Hit unhandled case 0 (Software caused connection abort) in parse_error.`

whereas when file.txt is that of RFC 0792 no warning message is output to the terminal (and gedit works).
