events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
First of all, I would like to thank the developers for their work on Pango. Your efforts are appreciated by millions of users across the world. To me, Pango was completely "invisible" until now which means it was working flawlessly.

After my terminal suddenly stopped working, I spent several days searching for cause and finally found this thread. I find it difficult to believe that something so important can just get dropped from functionality, and I can imagine that many other people are in similar position - frustrated and desperate.

I realize that development of any software sometimes calls for breaking changes, but perhaps whoever made this decision was not aware of how many of us rely on fixed fonts. I don't think forking is a solution here. In a world where everybody has a different opinion, lack of common agreement leads to chaos and disintegration of valuable things, which Pango definitely is.

To solve the problem, I tried to go with fonttosfnt. The conversion itself succeeded, but the end result looks so much worse than the original that it is useless (specifically, the vertical spacing is too big).

For now, my only solution is to downgrade pango. I sincerely hope that Pango/Harfbuzz guys will reconsider before dependencies break down my system.

events.target_title: When searching, pressing 'spacebar' selects the file

note.body:
This particular bug has been reported 3 years ago. It's probably completely forgotten about at this point, so a bit of a reminder won't hurt.

To add to the discussion, I'd like to propose a solution for all three bugs: do away with the pop-up search field altogether. It's a terrible UI practice to have UI elements that are hidden until something that needs to be performed *with* them is done. Just add (reinstante, rather) a dedicated search field. No more uncertainty about which UI element needs to capture the input or whether something is or isn't a token which gets away with breaking intuitive/logical functionality by the virtue of complying to a standard existing in a vacuum.

Simple example: I have a client with hundreds of LibreOffice files with similar names differing only by a few characters, that have spaces in them (because that's human-readable standard). This approach to searching makes finding them unusable: if spaces worked (which they can be forced to by re-focusing the search field manually after every word before the space is typed - obviously, that's a dirty workaround that breaks workflow), typing two words can narrow down those hundreds to a dozen. Typing just one word does nothing. GUI should be based around the needs of normal users without technical knowledge, so it is *indeed* quite frustrating that someone who clearly has some understanding of how the feature works under the hood chooses to grace us with an explanation of why it *needn't* be fixed after it was broken for 3 years - instead of just fixing it.

events.target_title: When searching, pressing 'spacebar' selects the file

note.body:
The current workaround we're using is the search in file explorer (Nemo) instead, which works exactly as expected and doesn't require renaming files. Hyphenating *can* hinder readability for older people with poor eyesight, which is the case here. Especially when you're dealing with hundreds of files.

The algorithm doesn't need to be changed at all if a separate, always-present search field is reinstated.

The reasoning provided is not very comprehensive, in my opinion. Again, bugs should be regarded from the standpoint of a layman user. Typing a search string and having focus suddenly hijacked by another UI element because a space was entered is unexpected and counter-intuitive behaviour. It doesn't work that way in Windows, it doesn't work that way in Linux file explorers, it doesn't work that way anywhere. Let's face it: someone, somewhere, somehow decided to take out that dedicated search field to make the UI more """sleek""", and hasn't bothered to see it through 100% - and now excuses are being made up for why its broken behaviour is allegedly right.

events.target_title: Freezing Constantly
Freezing Constantly
Copied text from rich text editors seems to be stored in the clipboard as a bitmap in X11

note.body: This is also affecting the WPS office a lot. It's not a random issue there; but rather a rule. WPS Writer correctly copies the text every other time you press CTRL+C.

events.target_title: Portals
Fix indention options

note.body:
I just came here to create a ticket to default to 4 spaces instead of a tab.  I mean, the [internet decided this a while ago](https://medium.com/@hoffa/400-000-github-repositories-1-billion-files-14-terabytes-of-code-spaces-or-tabs-7cfe0b5dd7fd#.fswbmzt2l).

Should I create additional tickets for auto-detection and support for [.editorconfig](https://editorconfig.org/)?

:grin:

events.target_title: reload the file when a symlink's target changes

note.body:
This still applies for version 3.34.2.
In fact, it appears, that "touch" does not have any effect at all. I guess, the currentness of the file is not determined by its date.

events.target_title: Backup did not start with error 'Could not log into Google servers OK'
Backup did not start with error 'Could not log into Google servers OK'

note.body: I switched to the latest deja-dup version (40.6) and deja-dup is now asking for access permission and after granting them it starts backing up.

events.target_title: Huge window size for such a simple tool

note.body:
I came to submit this same feature request and can offer a use-case. 

I use the timer several times a week for cooking etc. Clocks sort of gets the job done. It would be much more useful though if it could dynamically scale (as above) and then I could just pin the window to the top and shove it in a corner. Having a visible countdown is way more useful, but the window is currently limited to taking up about a quarter of the screen in 1080p, so it's not really practical.

events.target_title: Screen color picker gets wrong color
Screen color picker gets wrong color

note.body: Well, it seems that it is because of the color profile of my monitor. If I remove it, the screen picker gets the expected result.

events.target_title: Screen color picker gets wrong color
trnasparant bug
Screenshots using "Select area to grab" have translucent overlay

note.body:
I'm also experiencing this on Debian Buster.

```
gnome-2048/stable 3.30.0-2 amd64
gnome-screenshot/stable,now 3.30.0-2 amd64
```

I have two displays and the overlay artifact is present on whichever display I have marked as the `Primary Display` and not present on the secondary. If I change which is set to Primary the behavior swaps.

Update: After switching the Primary back, the behavior has changed again. Now screenshots from my Primary are clear and the secondary gets the overlay artifact.

GIMP PNG Export is not lossless due to hidden degradation, alpha channel goes monochrome
GIMP PNG Export is not lossless due to hidden degradation, alpha channel goes monochrome

note.body:
It would be nice probably with lossless formats to also put on the features / nice to have backlog some indication of if something's going to be lossless.

People really get confused by this. I remember once upon a time in a universe far far away when I had this dev that converted every image to gif obsessively and compulsively. Design would give us something with nice smooth gradients then I'd look at the site and it would be all jagged and choppy as hell.

This was also when bandwidth was still very important and scarce. He believed gif was superior because it produced smaller files but didn't realise it was getting better results than PNG because it was lossy due to 256 colours max. I don't understand how people are blind to the difference true colour and 256 makes to things like gradients but it happens. If you force PNG to 256 colours it's actually nearly always smaller than GIF. With gif the downgrade is automatically enforced but not with PNG.

I think this confusion still happens today. I think any lossless by default format should give some indication about why it's smaller if it's going to be lossy especially if it's chucking out information that people don't know about and would not think to be discrarded.

Most people also learn PNG is lossless and just assume it is so when they export and select all the options to preserve everything they don't expect it to be lossy. People could be losing data and not realising.

events.target_title: GIMP PNG Export is not lossless due to hidden degradation, alpha channel goes monochrome

note.body: Automatic does it. None of the manual options give enough granularity or clarity to either know which is right or set it without massive inflation (using more bits than needed for a channel to be lossless). I tried setting the most obvious only and I just got a file going from 600K to nearly 2MB.

events.target_title: GIMP PNG Export is not lossless due to hidden degradation, alpha channel goes monochrome

note.body: Setting it to 8bbp RGBA actually brings it down back to around 600K if I run optipng so in that specific case it would mean it's just not very optimal by default. Even with that in mind it still needs to make people aware if the auto option is lossy. Most people expect the auto to use the smallest sizes that would be lossless. IE you have 2 levels of alpha only then would it go 1 bit. I'm seeing it go 1 bit on auto with many (> 2, many pixel half transparent, maybe 1/3) levels of alpha.

Allow to mass-remove tags

note.body:
The feature "removing tags from multiple selected pictures" was present in Shotwell with version 0.18.0 already (verified just right now with an old ubuntu 14.04 system). The caption of the menu item of this action is constructed dynamically and it says in german translation "Schlagwort >>chilli<< von Fotos entfernen" (assumingly english: remove tag >>chilli<< from photos). 

This feature is lost in version 0.28.3 (verfied) or before (done no further checks). Perhaps it has been lost on the way working over dynamically constructed menu items. As far as I looked, it has been the only one of that kind (all other are static texts).

Additionally I would like to point out, that help in 0.28 still describes the behaviour of 0.18: 
*-> Hilfe / Fotos organisieren / Fotos markieren (Fotos durch Kennzeichnung organisieren) 
-> Um ein Stichwort von einem oder mehreren Fotos zu entfernen, wählen Sie zunächst das Stichwort in der Seitenleiste aus und danach die Fotos, von denen Sie die Stichworte entfernen wollen. Wählen Sie dann Stichworte ▸ Stichwort »[Name]« von Fotos entfernen oder klicken Sie mit der rechten Maustaste auf die Fotos und wählen Stichwort »[Name]« von Fotos entfernen.*

I would suggest changing this issue from "feature" to "bug". 

Furthermore I am missing dearly the option of mass removing tags from pictures because I am on - right now - reorganizing the hierarchical tags of my 40.000 pix gallery. Perhaps you could give priority to this fix? 

If dynamic captions of menu items are a problem, I would be glad with a static caption "remove (in tree) marked tag from selected pictures" :-) Please make recent functionality available again and please provide an update available for ubuntu 16.04 (0.28.5?).

In Bug 717838 another alternative is depicted: "Dragging photo(s) to tagname in tree on the left side with CTRL hold down should remove tags from pictures" - would be an option too. Even a more powerful one if you regard hierarchical tags. 
1. Dropping pics on parent tag (in tree) removes all child tags (that are present in tree beneath the drop target) including parent tag. 
1. Dropping pics on leaf tag removes only this tag (preserving ancestors). 

Example: 
tag tree is: /nature/fav, /nature/plant/rose, /nature/plant/tulip; photo1 has rose tag set (implicitly nature + plant + rose); photo2 has fav + tulip tag set; photo1+2 is selected, dragged and dropped, the mouse cursor shows the + sign, now holding down CTRL it changes to - sign.
1. drop on "plant", result: photo1: nature; photo2: fav (implicitly nature)
1. drop on "rose",  result: photo1: plant (implicitly nature); photo2: no change
1. drop on "nature", result: both possess no tags any more

Other tags (from adjacent tag hierarchies) of the photos are not modified.
